title: Flaches Modell (Flat Model) Dessert Fork, 1903
markings: Stamped "WW" (for Wiener Werkstatte) and Austrian hallmarks
provenance:
Estate of Magda Mautner [1]; 2002: acquired by Museum (from Torsten Broehan)






[1] Commissioned by Hertha Jaeger, member of the family of Magda Mautner von Markhof
creditline: Museum purchase from Friends of Applied Arts and Industrial Design, General Acquisitions Endowment, and Morrill Acquisitions Funds
description: Flat, rectangular in form, handle tapering very slightly towards head; four tines, the head with very slight cupping shape; four hollow beads attached at bottom edge of handle.
justification:
This silver dessert fork, designed by Viennese architect Josef Hoffmann, is from the pattern called Flat Model, the first model produced by the Wiener Werkstätte when it opened in 1903. The original service consisted of 33 different implements and all three of the Wiener Werkstätte’s founding members—Hoffmann, Koloman Moser, and Fritz Waerndorfer—had it made for their own use. Hoffmann’s Flat Model was the most radically modern flatware design introduced at the beginning of the 20th century and it has continued to exert tremendous influence on cutlery design throughout the past century.
This particular fork is purported to be part of the first Flat Model service ever produced, was commissioned by Hertha Jaeger, a member of the Magda Mautner von Markhof family. The set descended through the estate of Magda Mautner to the present source.
One of the features that makes this set so drastically modern for its time is the stark, flat, rectangular shape, ornamented only by the four beads at the handle terminals. The original designs and maquettes for the Flat Model show straight sided forks for dinner, fish, and dessert.[1] The shape of the fork was altered when the service went into commercial production in 1904—the head of the fork was given a more traditional definition by tapering and then extending the sides of the handle at the base of the fork head. Later Flat Model sets were produced with more traditional fork shapes.
Hoffmann’s Flat Model flatware is a pivotal design in modern cutlery and would be extremely desirable to add to the museum’s collection. It was the first and most radical design to reduce superfluous ornament and break down traditional boundaries between handles, blades, bowls, and tines. At the time, even the most adventurous patrons were not quite ready for this innovation: the Flat Model was only in production for four years. A similar revision is found in Hoffman’s Round Model of 1906. Although the Round Model drawings show a straight sided dessert fork, it was produced in the more traditional fork form. Hoffman’s other cutlery designs for the Wiener Werkstätte through the 1920s, also revert to more traditional forms.
The Flat Model and the Round Model were introduced to the public at the influential exhibition, Der gedeckte Tisch (The Dining Table), held in the Wiener Werkstätte showrooms in 1906. The Flat Model was criticized as “geometry, not art” and the service was called “uncomfortable” and "suggestive of anatomical instruments.”[2] It is difficult to find other contemporary cutlery designs with which to compare it—the Newbery set by Charles Rennie Mackintosh in 1902, with its thin tapering handles, comes close. It would be several decades before European flatware designers dared to introduce patterns with such dramatically reductive forms, such as the 1936 Gio Ponti stainless steel pattern for Krupp and the 1957 AJ pattern by Arne Jacobsen for Georg Jensen. None, however, have had the impact that Hoffmann’s did at the beginning of the century.
[1] Waltraud Neuwirth and Josef Franz Maria Hoffmann, Josef Hoffmann: Bestecke für die Wiener Werkstätte (Vienna: Selbstverlag W. Neuwirth, 1982).
[2] Neuwirth and Hoffmann, 29–31.

Gabriele Fahr Becker, Wiener Werkstaette 1903–1932 (Cologne: Taschen, 1995).

gallery_text: The avant-garde, modernist design group Wiener Werkstätte produced its first cutlery pattern the year of its founding, in 1903. Werkstätte co-founder Josef Hoffmann, after 1900, focused on reducing designs to their most functional and rudimentary elements, as he did in his Flat Model set, which was considered radical at the time. The pieces’ flatness, rectilinearity, and minimal ornamentation—four beads, a common motif of Hoffmann’s, at the base of the handles—made them entirely unlike traditional cutlery. The set was first presented to the public in 1906 at the Werkstätte showroom exhibition “Der geodeckte Tish” (“The Dining Table”). It was criticized as being uncomfortable to use, too focused on geometry, and resembling “anatomical instruments” rather than flatware. Critics disapproved of the lack of division between elements: in the fork, for instance, the prongs and handle were all one piece. The set was later made for commercial manufacture with slight alterations, notably a tapering of the fork’s sides to give a more traditional, though still undoubtedly modern, look. It remained in production just four years and it would be many years before Europe again saw such pared-down cutlery.
